publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 69.01

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: (the merit, but with the cessation of merits) it [= the merit] certainly does not live (anymore). [Although] possessions are the fruit of merits, [if they have] disappeared they will no longer sustain life. One of them (is the)
Even though possessions are the fruit of merits, they do not [re-]establish life when it has perished.

(cause) of life (of the beings, the other one), however, [is] the cause of the sustainment of life. [If] both (causes) cease, [then] this is the third cause of dying in a natural way, for the beings in the world. 1.
If both [scil. the merit, which causes life, and the possessions, which retain life] cease, that is the third cause for the beings in the world to die in a natural way.
(Death by effort), too, is three-fold. First, one dies through the efforts of oneself; second, [one dies] through the efforts of others; third,
Der eine stirbt durch die Bemühungen des eigenen Selbstes, der zweite durch die Bemühungen der anderen, der dritte (indessen) stirbt durch die Bemühungen (beider).
The one dies through the effort of [his] own self, the second through the efforts of others, the third, (however,) dies through the efforts (of both).
(however,) [one] dies through the efforts (of both). And that in which way? » In [the tune] yäṅkre: « Just like I have died by the efforts of [my] own self, without food,

(just so) I have died (through the efforts of others) on (your) command. By one’s own efforts as well as [by the efforts] of others, [this is] death of the third kind. These two, each three-fold, [are] (the cutting off)
of life. » (1.) Having heard (that), the king says: »Oh lord, [my] son, in your case I did not have the intention of killing you. Rather, only for the sake of making you speak I (ordered)
(to kill you. The prince) says: « [You] good father, you are not worthy to bring the mean death to others. See, oh lord! » In [the tune] devadatta: « (Death) cannot be vanquished,

[Du] guter Vater, du darfst den gemeinen Tod nicht anderen bringen. Sieh, o Herr: Im [Metrum] Devadatta || (Un)besiegbar ([ist] der Tod), ... schwer fernzuhalten [und] jedem das Leben raubend [ist] der Tod; alle Wünsche zunichte machend, wie eine drohende Krankheit das Leben nehmend, wie der Ozean (unersättlich), ...(spottend(?) der Kraft des Heilmittels [und] des Zauberspruchs, bodenlos wie die Unterwelt. Wie könnte den wohl ein Mitleidiger anderen bringen?

Good father, you must not bring base death to others. See, lord: in the Devadatta [metre] || (In)vincible ([is] death), ... death is difficult to keep away [and] robbing everybody's life, taking life away like a threatening sickness, (edacious) like the ocean, ... (mocking(?)) the power of cure [and] charm, bottomless like the underworld. How could a compassionate one ever bring this onto others?
... ; death [which] burns the life of everybody [is] difficult to keep away, destroying all wishes [and] taking the life like an oppressive sickness, like the ocean
(insatiable, ridiculing) the power of cure [and] charm, bottomless as the underworld. How could a compassionate one ever bring this [= death] onto others? » 1. The king says: « Oh compassionate
(lord, [my] son, exp)lain me what you said concerning the wheat: « If it is not consumed from the root. » But how (could) the wheat be (consumed) from the root? »
if it is not consumed at the root … (cf 26)

(The prince says:) « This matter [is] (not difficult) to understand. For, [if] a being consumes [already] the wheat during the season [of harvest], the fruit which he might have been able to obtain from it, he has eaten [it] (already) before.
Because if a being consumes the grain in the season, the fruit that he might have been able to obtain from it, …
(Therefore) this wheat has been consumed (from the root).» Having heard that, the king says: « Oh, what a wise prince, worthy ...

p.note: The translation is largely based on 24-25, and .
The restoration of the nt-participle katuṣant (with metrical reduction) from the verb katw- 'to ridicule' is based on Sieg [and Siegling's] suggestion to translate "spottend (?)".
This tune has 20/22/10/15 syllables, rhythm a=5/5/5/5, b=8/7/7, c=5/5, d=8/7.
Note that the syntactic division does not always fit the colon division, e.g. kältso ; wraske and mänt nu ; kāruṇik.
For the correct syntactic interpretation and restoration, cf. 277 with ref.

div.p: Edition37-38. Siegling's personal copy of p. 37 p. 38.

list.item: nutäṣ|(nu)|(täṣ) a1 (pñi ; pñintwis ārlu,neyo nu ; ṣakk a)ts mā_(TA)|mā śoṣ : #1a pñintwis|pñintwiss oko_(TA)|oko , niṣpalntu ; tākeñc penu , nutont śol ; mā_(TA)|mā śkaṃ ṣtämseñc : #1b ālak śolis|śoli|(s) a2 , (ṣurm nāṃtsu ; wrasaśśi ā,lak pe)nu ; śol ṣtmässi ṣurm : #1c āmpuk āreñc , säm trit ṣurm ; ṣäññāk wlässi , wrasaśśi ; ārkiśoṣṣaṃ : 1 #1d a3 (skāyluneyo wlalune) penu tri wäknā mäskatär • sas ṣñi āñmes skeysā wälläṣtär • wät ālu skeysā • trit a4 (penu āmpine ske)ysā wälläṣtär täm nu mänt wäknā • || yäṅkreyaṃ || # ṣñi|ṣñ= āyme skeysā , mätne näṣ ; tāpärk wläṃṣe , sne śwātsi|śwā|(tsi) a5 #1a (tämnek ālu , skeysā tñi) ; watkurā näṣ , wläṃṣāwe : #1b tmäk ṣñi skeysā , tmäk ālu ; tricäṃ lotkā , wlalune : #1c ceṣ wu sas sas , tri wäknā ; śol kärṣtāluneyäntu|kä|(rṣtālu,neyäntu) a6 (: 1 || #1d täm) (ka)klyuṣuräṣ wäl träṅkäṣ nātäk se mā_(TA)|mā ñi cwaṃ koluneṣi ime ṣeṣ • ṣñikek_(TA)|ṣñikek nu cu wenäṣlis mosann ats näṣ b1 (cu kossi wotkā • mäśkit träṅ)käṣ kāsu pācar mā_(TA)|mā āṣāṃ naṣt kärpiṃ wlalune ālu källātsi pälkār nātäk • || devadattenaṃ || # yukāl|yukā|(l) b2 mā_(TA)|(mā wlal_une ; – – – – – ; māski|mā)sky= ālñäl p_uk(i)s śol ; tsäkṣant wlalune : #1a puk ākālntu , spärkṣant kältso ; wraske oki , śol sumnānt ; sāmudr oki|o|(ki) b3 , (asinät :) #1b (kat_uṣant sāṃ)tkaṣi ; maṃnträṣiṃ tampe : #1c pāṭāll oki , sne päts mänt nu ; kāruṇik cam , ālu kliṣ : 1 || #1d wäl träṅkäṣ kāruṇik|kāru|(ṇik) b4 (nātäk se pākṣi)ññā-ñi kucne tu wsār pälkoräṣ weñāṣt kupprene tsmāraṃ mā_(TA)|mā tāppus tāṣ mänt nu wsār tsmāraṃ tāpus|tā|(ppus) b5 (tākiṣ • mäśkit träṅkäṣ mā_(TA)|mā māski) kärsnāl saṃ wram k_uyalte yusār praṣṭā wrasom wsār tāpaṣ kucne tmäṣ oko_(TA)|oko kälpāl tāṣ cam säm|sä|(m) b6 (neṣā tāppu tāk tämyo tsmāraṃ t)āppus sām wsār mäskatär • täm kaklyuṣuräṣ wäl träṅkäṣ ote täpreṃ knānmāṃ mäśkit āṣāṃ

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1 Even though possessions are the fruit of merits, they do not [re-]establish life when it has perished. 261
a2 If both [scil. the merit, which causes life, and the possessions, which retain life] cease, that is the third cause for the beings in the world to die in a natural way. 643
b4 if it is not consumed at the root … (cf [[Sieg, Übers. II]]: 26) 648
b5 Because if a being consumes the grain in the season, the fruit that he might have been able to obtain from it, … 277


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3-4 Der eine stirbt durch die Bemühungen des eigenen Selbstes, der zweite durch die Bemühungen der anderen, der dritte (indessen) stirbt durch die Bemühungen (beider). 113
b1-3 [Du] guter Vater, du darfst den gemeinen Tod nicht anderen bringen. Sieh, o Herr: Im [Metrum] Devadatta || (Un)besiegbar ([ist] der Tod), ... schwer fernzuhalten [und] jedem das Leben raubend [ist] der Tod; alle Wünsche zunichte machend, wie eine drohende Krankheit das Leben nehmend, wie der Ozean (unersättlich), ...(spottend(?) der Kraft des Heilmittels [und] des Zauberspruchs, bodenlos wie die Unterwelt. Wie könnte den wohl ein Mitleidiger anderen bringen? 191-2, 388-9


Restorations violating subcaesuras:
a1: (ārluneyo)
a2: (ālak)
a5: kä(rṣtāluneyäntu)
(BK)

b1: (philological commentary) The ᵤ in the restored (katᵤṣant) would probably not be due to metrical reduction. A root-final w in TA only becomes syllabic in word-final position but not before a consonant (see e.g. ritwṣant, spārtwṣant, tsārwṣant). I don't think a form such as katuṣant is attested at all. (BK)

a4: [[TochSprR(A)]]: 252 analyze ṣñāyme〈s〉 skeysā. This would also match the translation. (BK)

(The life does not make disappear even) a1 (the merit, but with the cessation of merits) it [= the merit] certainly does not live (anymore). [Although] possessions are the fruit of merits, [if they have] disappeared they will no longer sustain life. One of them (is the) a2 (cause) of life (of the beings, the other one), however, [is] the cause of the sustainment of life. [If] both (causes) cease, [then] this is the third cause of dying in a natural way, for the beings in the world. 1. a3 (Death by effort), too, is three-fold. First, one dies through the efforts of oneself; second, [one dies] through the efforts of others; third, a4 (however,) [one] dies through the efforts (of both). And that in which way? » In [the tune] yäṅkre: « Just like I have died by the efforts of [my] own self, without food, a5 (just so) I have died (through the efforts of others) on (your) command. By one’s own efforts as well as [by the efforts] of others, [this is] death of the third kind. These two, each three-fold, [are] (the cutting off) a6 of life. » (1.) Having heard (that), the king says: »Oh lord, [my] son, in your case I did not have the intention of killing you. Rather, only for the sake of making you speak I (ordered) b1 (to kill you. The prince) says: « [You] good father, you are not worthy to bring the mean death to others. See, oh lord! » In [the tune] devadatta: « (Death) cannot be vanquished, b2 ... ; death [which] burns the life of everybody [is] difficult to keep away, destroying all wishes [and] taking the life like an oppressive sickness, like the ocean b3 (insatiable, ridiculing) the power of cure [and] charm, bottomless as the underworld. How could a compassionate one ever bring this [= death] onto others? » 1. The king says: « Oh compassionate b4 (lord, [my] son, exp)lain me what you said concerning the wheat: « If it is not consumed from the root. » But how (could) the wheat be (consumed) from the root? » b5 (The prince says:) « This matter [is] (not difficult) to understand. For, [if] a being consumes [already] the wheat during the season [of harvest], the fruit which he might have been able to obtain from it, he has eaten [it] (already) before. b6 (Therefore) this wheat has been consumed (from the root).» Having heard that, the king says: « Oh, what a wise prince, worthy ...
Gerd Carling, Georges-Jean Pinault, Melanie Malzahn

The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. II]]: 24-25, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

a1. This tune has 4x18 syllables, rhythm 7/7/4.

a4. This tune has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7.

b1-b3. This tune has 20/22/10/15 syllables, rhythm a=5/5/5/5, b=8/7/7, c=5/5, d=8/7.

b1. The restoration of the nt-participle katuṣant (with metrical reduction) from the verb katw- 'to ridicule' is based on Sieg [and Siegling's] suggestion to translate "spottend (?)".

b2-b3. Note that the syntactic division does not always fit the colon division, e.g. kältso ; wraske and mänt nu ; kāruṇik.

b5. For the correct syntactic interpretation and restoration, cf. [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 277 with ref.

a1 /// ts mā śo_ṣ\• : pñintwiss oko niṣpalntu tākeñc penu nuton_t\• śol mā śkaṃ _ṣ_t_amseñcä\ : āla_k\• śol[i] a2 /// [n]u śo_l\• ṣt_m_assi ṣur_m\• : āmpu_k\• āreñcä\ _s_am tri_t\• ṣur_m\ _ṣ_aññā_k\• w_l_assi wrasaśśi ārkiśoṣṣaṃ : 1 a3 /// ○ penu tri wäknā _m_aska_t_a_r\• • sa_s\• ṣñi āñme_s\• skeysā wä_l_l_a_ṣ_t_a_r\• • wä_t\• ālu skeysā • tri_t\• a4 /// ○ ysā wä_l_l_a_ṣ_t_a_r\• _t_am nu _m_an_t\• wäknā • || yäṅkreyaṃ || ṣñ= āyme skeysā _m_atne _n_aṣ tā_p_ar_k\ w_l_aṃṣe sne śwā a5 /// [wa]tkurā _n_a_ṣ\• w_l_aṃṣāwe : _t_m_a_k\• ṣñi skeysā _t_m_a_k\• ālu tricäṃ lotkā wlalune : ceṣ wu sas sas tri wäknā śo_l _k_a a6 /// klyuṣu_r_a_ṣ wä_l t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\• nā_t_ak se mā ñi cwaṃ koluneṣi ime ṣe_ṣ\• • ṣñikek nu cu we_n_aṣlis mosann at_s _n_a_ṣ\• b1 /// (·)[_k_a]_ṣ\• kāsu pācar mā āṣāṃ na_ṣ_t\• _k_arpiṃ wlalune ālu _k_allātsi _p_alkār nā_t_a_k\• • || devadattenaṃ || yukā b2 /// sky= ālñä_l\• p_uk(·)s śo_l t_s_akṣan_t\• wlalune : pu_k\• ākālntu _s_p_arkṣan_t\• _k_altso wraske oki śol sumnān_t\• sāmudr o b3 /// ○ tkaṣi maṃnt_r_aṣiṃ tampe : pāṭāll oki sne _p_at_s\• _m_an_t nu kāruṇik ca_m\• ālu kli_ṣ\• : 1 || wä_l t_r_aṅ_k_aṣ kāru b4 /// ○ ññā-ñi kucne tu wsār _p_alko_r_aṣ weñā_ṣ_t\• kupprene tsmāraṃ mā tāppus tā_ṣ\• _m_an_t nu wsā_r\• tsmāraṃ tā b5 /// _k_arsnāl saṃ wra_m\• k_uyalte yusār praṣṭā wraso_m\• wsār tāpa_ṣ\• kucne _t_m_a_ṣ\• oko _k_alpāl tā_ṣ\• cam _s_a b6 /// ·āppus sā_m\• wsār _m_aska_t_a_r\• • _t_am kaklyuṣu_r_a_ṣ\• wä_l t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\• ote _t_apreṃ knānmāṃ _m_aśki_t\• āṣāṃ

div.p:
Restorations violating subcaesuras: a1: (ārluneyo) a2: (ālak) a5: kä(rṣtāluneyäntu) (BK)

: (philological commentary) The ᵤ in the restored (katᵤṣant) would probably not be due to metrical reduction. A root-final w in TA only becomes syllabic in word-final position but not before a consonant (see e.g. ritwṣant, spārtwṣant, tsārwṣant). I don't think a form such as katuṣant is attested at all. (BK)

: <citedRange>252</citedRange></bibl> analyze <hi>ṣñāyme〈s〉 skeysā</hi>. This would also match the translation. (BK)</p></project_comment>
